function ServiceInformation() { return (

Business Registration Service

Register your business with the Government of Alberta to operate legally and access business services.

Required Information:

  • Proposed business name (or confirmation you'll use your legal name)
  • Business address
  • Nature of business activities
  • Names and addresses of all partners/directors

Required Documents:

  • Government-issued photo ID
  • Proof of business address (lease, utility bill, etc.)
  • Partnership agreement (if applicable)

Processing Times:

  • Online registration: 1-2 business days
  • Mail registration: 5-10 business days
  • In-person registration: Same day (if all documents are complete)

What happens after registration:

  1. You'll receive a Certificate of Registration
  2. Your business will be listed in the Corporate Registry
  3. You can apply for required licenses and permits
  4. You'll need to file annual returns to maintain registration

Current Fees (2024):

  • Sole proprietorship: $60
  • Partnership: $70
  • Corporation: $100

Payment Methods:

  • Credit card (Visa, MasterCard, American Express)
  • Debit card (online and in-person)
  • Cheque or money order (mail registration only)

Note: Fees are non-refundable, even if registration is denied.
); }

commonPatterns.name: FAQ-Style Information
commonPatterns.description: Question and answer format for common inquiries
commonPatterns.code:
function SupportFAQ() { return (

Frequently Asked Questions

Yes, you can change your business name, but the process depends on your business structure:

Sole Proprietorship or Partnership:

You'll need to register a new business name and close the old registration. This involves:

  1. Registering the new business name
  2. Updating all licenses and permits
  3. Notifying banks, suppliers, and customers
  4. Filing final returns for the old registration

Corporation:

You can file an Amendment to change your corporate name. Contact the Corporate Registry for specific requirements.

Generally yes, if you're operating a business for profit, you need to register regardless of location.

Exceptions:

  • Occasional sales of personal items
  • Hobby activities where profit isn't the primary goal
  • Some farm operations (check specific requirements)

Additional Considerations for Home Businesses:

  • Check municipal zoning bylaws
  • Verify homeowner/tenant insurance coverage
  • Consider separate business phone line and address
  • Understand tax implications for home office expenses

These are two different legal processes with different implications:

Business Registration (Sole Proprietorship/Partnership):

  • Simpler and less expensive
  • Personal liability for business debts
  • Business income is personal income for tax purposes
  • Easier to dissolve

Incorporation (Corporation):

  • More complex setup and ongoing requirements
  • Limited personal liability protection
  • Separate tax entity
  • Can have multiple shareholders
  • Perpetual existence

Consider consulting with a lawyer or accountant to determine the best structure for your business.
); }

commonMistakes.mistake: Using multiple Details components instead of Accordion for related disclosures
commonMistakes.why: Multiple Details lack visual cohesion and master controls for grouped content
commonMistakes.instead: Use Accordion for multiple related sections, Details for single disclosures
commonMistakes.example:
// ❌ Wrong - multiple details for related content
<GoabDetails heading="Personal Info Help">...</GoabDetails>
<GoabDetails heading="Employment Help">...</GoabDetails>
<GoabDetails heading="Document Help">...</GoabDetails>

// ✅ Correct - accordion for grouped content
<GoabAccordion heading="Personal Info Help">...</GoabAccordion>
<GoabAccordion heading="Employment Help">...</GoabAccordion>

commonMistakes.mistake: Using Details for critical information that all users must see
commonMistakes.why: Important information may be missed if hidden by default
commonMistakes.instead: Use Details only for supplementary or optional information

commonMistakes.mistake: Writing vague or non-descriptive heading text
commonMistakes.why: Users can't determine if the content is relevant to their needs
commonMistakes.instead: Use specific, descriptive headings that clearly indicate what will be revealed

commonMistakes.mistake: Including too much content that makes expanded area overwhelming
commonMistakes.why: Defeats the purpose of progressive disclosure if content is still overwhelming
commonMistakes.instead: Keep expanded content focused and well-structured with headings and lists
